intro: Similisinocarum, commonly known as the "ghost fern," is a rare and ancient plant species belonging to the family Blechnaceae. It is characterized by its delicate, lacy fronds that resemble the appearance of ghostly apparitions, hence its common name. The plant is typically found in moist, shaded environments, such as forest floors or rocky crevices. Its reproductive structures, including sporangia, are clustered on the underside of its fronds, a feature common among ferns. Due to its limited distribution and fragile nature, Similisinocarum is considered a rare and endangered species in its native habitat.
